Key Arguments: The bill represents government overreach and abuse of power, threatening freedom of speech and thought.
The definitions of misinformation and disinformation are too broad, allowing for potential censorship of almost any information.
The bill could lead to government-controlled public discourse, akin to totalitarian regimes.
The definition of harm is overly broad and could be abused.
Excluded content provisions protect government statements from being classified as misinformation or disinformation.
The implementation of the bill would lead to digital platforms acting as censors under government influence.
The complaints process is ineffective and would worsen under the bill.
Notable Quotes: Power tends to corrupt and absolute power corrupts absolutely.
This bill and freedom of expression cannot coexist.
The fact that this Bill has been tabled is indicates that the government has a significant distrust of the Australian citizen.
Under no circumstances do I want to see the deadly blight of centralised information control embedded in the day-to-day life of this country.
